scenes.title: Dorothy Returns Home
scenes.summary: Dorothy reunites with Aunt Em after her adventures.
scenes.chapter: Chapter XXIV Home Again
scenes.text:
Aunt Em had just come out of the house to water the cabbages when she
looked up and saw Dorothy running toward her.
"My darling child!" she cried, folding the little girl in her arms and
covering her face with kisses. "Where in the world did you come from?"
"From the Land of Oz," said Dorothy gravely. "And here is Toto, too.
And oh, Aunt Em! I'm so glad to be at home again!"

characters.name: Aunt Em
characters.quote: My darling child!

characters.name: Dorothy
characters.quote: And oh, Aunt Em! I'm so glad to be at home again!

characters.name: Dorothy
characters.quote: Aunt Em had been so startled by the child's laughter that she would scream and press her hand upon her heart whenever Dorothy's merry voice reached her ears.
characters.explanation: A soft pink represents Dorothy's innocence and joy, reflecting her cheerful nature.

characters.name: Aunt Em
characters.quote: The sun and wind had changed her, too. They had taken the sparkle from her eyes and left them a sober gray; they had taken the red from her cheeks and lips, and they were gray also.
characters.explanation: A gray color reflects Aunt Em's weary and hardworking nature.

characters.name: Uncle Henry
characters.quote: He worked hard from morning till night and did not know what joy was.
characters.explanation: A brownish-red reflects Uncle Henry's hardworking and stern nature.

characters.name: Toto
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.explanation: A deep black represents Toto's loyalty and protective nature towards Dorothy.

characters.name: Witch Of The North
characters.quote: You are welcome, most noble Sorceress, to the land of the Munchkins. We are so grateful to you for having killed the Wicked Witch of the East.
characters.explanation: A soft blue symbolizes the Witch of the North's kindness and protective nature.

characters.name: Three Men
characters.quote: No quote available

characters.name: Munchkin
characters.quote: The Witch of the East was proud of those silver shoes, and there is some charm connected with them; but what it is we never knew.
characters.explanation: A peach color represents the Munchkins' cheerful and friendly demeanor.

characters.name: Boq
characters.quote: You must be a great sorceress.
characters.explanation: A bright green represents Boq's friendly and welcoming personality.

characters.name: Scarecrow
characters.quote: My name is Dorothy, and I am going to the Emerald City, to ask the Great Oz to send me back to Kansas.
characters.explanation: A light yellow symbolizes the Scarecrow's desire for brains and his sunny disposition.

characters.name: The Child
characters.quote: Won't you tell me a story, while we are resting?

characters.name: The Old Crow
characters.quote: I wonder if that farmer thought to fool me in this clumsy manner. Any crow of sense could see that you are only stuffed with straw.

characters.name: Tin Woodman
characters.quote: This is a great comfort.
characters.explanation: A metallic silver represents the Tin Woodman's body and his longing for a heart.

characters.name: Lion
characters.quote: I know it. I've always known it. But how can I help it?
characters.explanation: A golden yellow reflects the Lion's royal status and his struggle with cowardice.

characters.name: Stork
characters.quote: I always like to help anyone in trouble. But I must go now, for my babies are waiting in the nest for me.

characters.quote: No quote available

characters.name: Mice
characters.quote: The mice, though small, demonstrate their capability by pulling the large truck.

characters.name: The Woman
characters.quote: What do you want, child, and why is that great Lion with you?

characters.name: The Man
characters.quote: Are you sure that Oz will see you?

characters.name: Guardian Of The Gates
characters.quote: It has been many years since anyone asked me to see Oz.
characters.explanation: A brown color represents the Guardian's earthy and grounded role in the story.

characters.name: Soldier
characters.quote: Step inside, and I will carry your message to him.
characters.explanation: A bright blue reflects the Soldier's bravery and loyalty to the Emerald City.

characters.name: Oz
characters.quote: I am Oz, the Great and Terrible. Who are you, and why do you seek me?
characters.explanation: A rich green symbolizes the Emerald City and the hope that Oz represents for Dorothy.

characters.name: Green Girl
characters.quote: Make yourself perfectly at home.

characters.name: Wicked Witch Of The West
characters.quote: Go to those people, and tear them to pieces.
characters.explanation: A dark purple reflects the Wicked Witch's evil nature and her connection to dark magic.

characters.name: Leader Of The Wolves
characters.quote: Are you not going to make them your slaves?

characters.name: King Crow
characters.quote: You have called us for the third and last time. What do you command?

characters.name: The Winkies
characters.quote: No quote available

characters.name: Winged Monkey Leader

characters.name: Tiger

characters.name: Farmer's Wife
characters.quote: It is not a great way,

characters.name: Girl Soldier
characters.quote: Why have you come to the South Country?

characters.name: Glinda

characters.explanation: A bright pink symbolizes Glinda's beauty and her role as a good witch.

locations.name: Kansas
locations.quote: Dorothy lived in the midst of the great Kansas prairies, with Uncle Henry, who was a farmer, and Aunt Em, who was the farmer's wife.

locations.name: Uncle Henry's House
locations.quote: Uncle Henry sat upon the doorstep and looked anxiously at the sky, which was even grayer than usual.

locations.name: Dorothy's House
locations.quote: When Dorothy stood in the doorway and looked around, she could see nothing but the great gray prairie on every side.

locations.name: Land Of Oz
locations.quote: The cyclone had set the house down very gently—for a cyclone—in the midst of a country of marvelous beauty.

locations.name: Emerald City
locations.quote: Dorothy and her friends are awed by the Emerald City and learn from Oz that they must defeat the Wicked Witch to achieve their desires.

locations.name: Munchkin's House
locations.quote: The people greeted Dorothy kindly, and invited her to supper and to pass the night with them.

locations.name: Yellow Brick Road
locations.quote: The road to the City of Emeralds is paved with yellow brick, so you cannot miss it.

locations.name: Cornfield
locations.quote: Dorothy leaned her chin upon her hand and gazed thoughtfully at the Scarecrow.

locations.name: Forest
locations.quote: The road was still paved with yellow brick, but these were much covered by dried branches and dead leaves from the trees.

locations.name: Cottage In The Woods
locations.quote: Dorothy entered and found a bed of dried leaves in one corner.

locations.name: Forest Clearing
locations.quote: They turned and walked through the forest a few steps, when Dorothy discovered something shining in a ray of sunshine.

locations.name: Empty Basket
locations.quote: What worried her most was that the bread was nearly gone, and another meal for herself and Toto would empty the basket.

locations.name: On The Journey
locations.quote: They were obliged to camp out that night under a large tree in the forest.

locations.name: Ditch
locations.quote: When they crept up to the edge and looked into it they could see it was also very deep, and there were many big, jagged rocks at the bottom.

locations.name: Across The Tree
locations.quote: The Tin Woodman set to work at once, and so sharp was his axe that the tree was soon chopped nearly through.

locations.name: River
locations.quote: They suddenly came upon a broad river, flowing swiftly just before them.

locations.name: Under The Trees
locations.quote: So they found a cozy place under the trees where they slept well until the morning.

locations.name: Flower-filled Path
locations.quote: The path was lined with beautiful flowers that filled the air with their sweet fragrance.

locations.name: Poppy Field
locations.quote: The travelers face challenges crossing a river and navigating a poppy field, leading to moments of teamwork and sacrifice.

locations.name: Open Field
locations.quote: The sun shone brightly over the open field, making it a beautiful sight.

locations.name: Queen's Domain
locations.quote: The Queen of the Field Mice welcomed them into her domain with open arms.

locations.name: Queen Of The Field Mice's Domain
locations.quote: The Queen of the Field Mice offered her assistance to the travelers in their time of need.

locations.name: On The Grass
locations.quote: They sat down on the grass to rest and enjoy the beautiful day.

locations.name: Near The Sleeping Lion
locations.quote: They cautiously approached the sleeping lion, careful not to disturb him.

locations.name: Field Near Dorothy's Home
locations.quote: The field was filled with flowers and the sound of birds chirping.

locations.name: Beside The Lion
locations.quote: They gathered beside the lion, feeling a mix of fear and awe.

locations.name: Couch In A Corner
locations.quote: The couch in the corner was a comfortable spot to rest after a long day.

locations.name: Palace Of Oz
locations.quote: The palace was grand and magnificent, a sight to behold.

locations.name: Wicked Witch's Castle
locations.quote: The castle loomed ominously in the distance, a reminder of the danger they faced.

locations.name: Near Dorothy
locations.quote: They stayed close to Dorothy, knowing she was their leader.

locations.name: Rocky Plain
locations.quote: The rocky plain was difficult to traverse, but they pressed on.

locations.name: Dorothy's Room
locations.quote: Dorothy's room was filled with memories of her life before Oz.

locations.name: Tall Tree
locations.quote: The tall tree provided shade and comfort as they rested beneath it.

locations.name: Winkies' Workshop
locations.quote: The workshop was bustling with activity as the Winkies worked on their crafts.

locations.name: Witch's Cupboard
locations.quote: The cupboard was filled with strange and magical items.

locations.name: Golden Cap
locations.quote: The golden cap was a symbol of power and magic in the land of Oz.

locations.name: Unknown Location
locations.quote: They found themselves in an unknown location, unsure of where to go next.

locations.name: Dorothy's Camp
locations.quote: The camp was a safe haven for Dorothy and her friends as they rested.

locations.name: Balloon Launch Site
locations.quote: The launch site was filled with excitement as they prepared for the journey home.

locations.name: Tin Woodman's Location
locations.quote: The Tin Woodman's location was marked by the sound of his axe chopping wood.

locations.name: The City Gate
locations.quote: The city gate stood tall and imposing, welcoming travelers to the Emerald City.

locations.name: Forest Edge
locations.quote: The edge of the forest was a transition point between the wild and the civilized.

locations.name: Top Of The Wall
locations.quote: From the top of the wall, they could see the vast landscape of Oz.

locations.name: On The Top Of The Wall
locations.quote: They stood on top of the wall, feeling a sense of accomplishment.

locations.name: China Country
locations.quote: The delicate china country was a beautiful but fragile place.

locations.name: Disagreeable Country
locations.quote: The disagreeable country was filled with challenges and obstacles.

locations.name: Spider's Lair
locations.quote: The spider's lair was dark and foreboding, a place of danger.

locations.name: Hill
locations.quote: The hill provided a vantage point to see the surrounding area.

locations.name: Farmer's House
locations.quote: The farmer's house was a welcoming sight after a long journey.

locations.name: Good Witch's Castle
locations.quote: The Good Witch's castle was a place of safety and magic.
